name: coke production, wet quenching | coal tar | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/29483/documentation

This multioutput-process represents the supply of coke by using the wet quenching (CWQ) technology, producing coal gas, coal tar, sulfur and benzene as a byproduct whithin the geography of China.;The dataset is based on the article “Life cycle environmental performance of by-product coke production in China” from Liu, X. and Yuan, Z. (2016).

Activity starts with the reception of coal at plant-site.

The activity ends with the supply of 1 kg of coke, considering the by-product recovery, to the chinese and global market. Transport is not included.
category: C:Manufacturing/19:Manufacture of coke and refined petroleum products/191:Manufacture of coke oven products/1910:Manufacture of coke oven products

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Domestic coking coal reserves for coke production are very rich;and centrally distributed in Shanxi, Anhui and Shandong Provinces,;which accounted for approximately 70% of the Chinese total coking;coal resources (Fan, W.T., 2005. Chinese Coking Coal Resources, Production and Quality. China National Coal Association, Beijing, China.) By that it is assumed for the entire country.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Wet quenching plays a significant role in the production of coke and is the traditional procedure. In the coke-making process, coal is heated in an oxygen-depleted environment to remove volatile components and produce coke. Wet quenching is employed to rapidly cool down the hot coke and stabilize its structure. The coke is typically transferred to a quenching tower, where it comes into contact with water sprays or is submerged in water. This immediate cooling prevents the coke from further reacting with oxygen, which could result in its combustion. Additionally, wet quenching helps to harden and strengthen the coke, making it more suitable for transportation and handling.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset is built based on the results of the study by Liu and Yuan (2016). For more information, please see the published source.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Bases on a study that compiles LCI data pertaining to most of the life cycle stages of "byproduct" coke production through site-specific interviews and measurements. Nevertheless, for upstream processes like raw material extraction, production, transportation, and certain processes lacking emission data, it relies on background information from commercial inventory databases, expert estimations, and published literature. The majority of the data concerning coke production is sourced from medium-sized coke production enterprises located in Shanxi Province and Jiangsu Province, China, with annual production capacities ranging from 0.7 to 1 million tons of metallurgical coke.
The study's system boundaries encompass several stages, including raw material acquisition, on-site coal preparation, thermal distillation, coke handling and storage, and by-product recovery. Air pollutants generated during charging, pushing, quenching, coke screening, and combustion are collected using air pollution control devices (APCDs).
The authors primarily focus on-site air emissions and water pollutants, as all solid wastes generated during production are collected and reintegrated with coals. Emissions of conventional air pollutants such as PM, SO2, and NO2 are calculated based on on-site environmental monitoring data. CO2, CH4, and CO emissions are derived from the Ecoinvent Database v2.2.
